content.description:
Tweedle Dumb is climbed from the west.  Climb up to the notch between the towers then aid up the bolts to an easy scramble to the summit and a two bolt anchor.

Out of the notch you climb over a big boulder that looks to be supporting the giant block that makes up the top of the tower.  It seemed solid but it can't hurt to think light thoughts.
content.protection:
-Draws and possibly a couple cams

-Anchor tat

-Single rope
content.location: Tweedle Dee and Tweedle Dumb are just south of Harts and Minds Tower. Hike a few hundred yards SE from the the confluence. Both routes are climbed from the west.

content.description: Tweedle Dee is climbed from the west.  Climb up to the notch between the towers then chimney past some loose rock to a big ledge.  Aid up the three bolts then tension around the corner to the right and free climb up the soft rock to a two bolt anchor on the top.
content.protection:
-Draws and possibly a couple cams

-Anchor tat

-Single rope
content.location: Tweedle Dee and Tweedle Dumb are just south of Harts and Minds Tower. Hike a few hundred yards SE from the the confluence. Both routes are climbed from the west.

content.description:
This route climbs the beautiful crack that ascends up the dihedral on the east side of the tower. The crack climbs all the way to the summit of the tower.  Throughout the pitch you climb everything from fingers to chimney.

We found a very faded plaque at the base with “The Party’s Over 5.11” on it.  We felt like the pitch was a bit harder than that but maybe we were tired.

The anchor is less than ideal. It consists of a good bolt that is backed up with an old piece of rope with a jammed knot in a crack.

It’s possible but not easy to rappel this tower with a single 70m rope if you rap to the notch of ‘Hartworm Tower’. Then one more rap to the east will get you to the ground.
content.protection:
Quad .75, 3

Triple .3-.5, 1-2

Double 4

Single 5 or 6

Slings

Two 60m ropes
content.location: This tower is located on the SW side of the point that is just north of the confluence. This tower is 30’ west of Hartworm Tower.

content.description:
P1:

Dual hand cracks in a R-facing corner past a couple hallow blocks to a ledge, up softer squeeze to a big ledge and a two bolt chain anchor. (5.9, 60')

P2:

Move belay on huge ledge to base of sweet left facing corner(2x #3 belay). Fist up clean corner on good rock. (5.10, 80')

P3:

OW/Chimney/squirm to notch, bolts to top with some wild free starfish stemming.  (5.9, A0, 130')

Note: Watch your ends on rappel, both raps are close.
content.protection:
-Single .2, .4, .5, 5

-Double 2, 3

-Three to five #4s

-Anchor tat for summit (15')

-single 70m rope
content.location: The Infarction is on the northern tip of Bobbys Butte.  The route starts on the east side of the tower.

content.description:
P1:

Climb wide hands to OW on the right side of a large flake like feature. From its top continue ledge to ledge via stemboxes to the saddle and a two bolt chain anchor.  (5.10, 115' watch your ends!)

P2:

Climb the hangerless bolt ladder to the summit and a two bolt anchor. (C1, 100')
content.location: This tower is located on the SE side of the point that is just north of the confluence.  There is another tower just west of Hartworm, which has an anchor on top.  The route on Hartworm starts on the NE side of the tower, just left of a single pitch route with a plaque 'Broken Hart 5.10'.

content.description: This route climbs the large crack/chimney system on the south side of the butte.  This route has no anchor on top and was free soloed up and down.  The climbing feels secure but as always in the desert be careful of the loose sandy rock.
content.location: Harts Draw Rincon Butte is approximately a half mile down harts draw from the confluence.  (.5 miles north of the confluence).

content.description:
P1:

Climb up a flared OW dihedral with hand sized gear in the back to a ledge.  Continue up a finger sized shallow dihedral to another ledge. Climb the stembox with thin gear as pro to a ledge with a two bolt anchor. Be careful of the loose rock. (5.10)

P2:

Squeeze onto the ledge on the north side of the tower and then chimney up 20' to a horizontal crack that takes finger sized gear.  Continue 15' to the top of the shorter pillar, then up the 3 bolt ladder to a two bolt anchor.  (5.7 C1)

P3:

Climb past very soft rock up to the summit 10' and back down to the anchor. (5.5)
content.protection:
-Double set of cams .3-3

-Rivets or stoppers

-Anchor tat

-Single rope
content.location: This tower is obvious sticking out on a point a couple hundred yards SE from the confluence.  The route climbs the south side of the tower.

content.description: Climb the obvious crack to the saddle passing a couple steeper sections along the way.  From the notch, chimney unprotected for about 20-25 feet to a hangerless bolt ladder that takes you to the summit with a two bolt anchor.  On the FA a #1 camalot was helpful for the mantel onto the summit but this is likely no longer needed because of the anchor.
content.protection:
-Singles .3-.75

-Doubles 1-3

-rivets or stoppers

-2 ropes (I rappelled with one 70m rope but had to down climb easy loose rock for 15')
content.location: This tower is on the SW corner of Bobbys Butte.  The route starts on the east side of the tower and follows a crack system up to the notch.

content.description:
Pitch 1:

Climb the clean flared crack that gradually widens.  End on a nice ledge with a gear anchor. 5.9, 60’

Pitch 2:

Climb the crack in the left that slowly narrows from 3 to .5 end on another ledge. There is a rap station here but it would be less comfortable than a gear belay. 5.10, 40’

Pitch 3:

Chimney up to the start of the bolt ladder. Then climb the bolts to the top past a 5.7 mantle in the middle. It’s probably 40’ to the start of the bolts with shit for gear. Be careful. 5.9 C0, 110’

A 5.7 mantle will get you on the summit from the anchor.

Both anchors have chain, no tat needed.
content.location: This tower is in the small side canyon west of the confluence of Hart’s Draw and Bobby’s Hole Canyon.  The route starts on the NE side in a flared crack.

content.description: Scramble 4th class up the slope on the SE side of the butte to a sloping ledge.  Place an optional big cam in the huecos below the first bolt or just clip the first bolt.  Thin sandy slab climbing past two bolts leads to a thin crack and then two more bolts to easier ground and a two bolt chain anchor up and right.
content.location: Bobbys Butte is the large butte just east of the confluence.
